episode_title: Roll-Ups vs. Holdcos: Understanding the Key Differences and Benefits with Dzmitry Miranovich
transcript:
ï»¿Nikolas Hulewsky (00:00.334)
Tell me, I'll mark it and we can, we'll edit it out later. Okay, Dimitri, I'm stoked, excited to talk to you today. I've been trying to get you on for over a year. You have a roll-up that you're working on right now, a veterinary clinics. You have over 20 of them. And I think people are very curious about this roll-up hold co model, especially when they haven't done it before. And they have a lot of, I guess, ideas about what it actually is. What is, in your opinion,


Dzmitry Miranovich (00:02.281)
Yeah, perfect.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:30.2)
the worst thing about a hold co company or roll up and what do you feel like is the best thing? Let's start with the worst first.


Dzmitry Miranovich (00:36.563)
Yeah, well, thanks for having me on. And I'm glad we finally are able to do this. Yeah, so I'd say, so holdcos and rollups are, in my mind, are very different. I think some people might be using those terms interchangeably. Generally in my mind, when people say a holdcode, they refer to an organization which has some sort of corporate overhead, corporate systems, like a...


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:40.526)
Of


Dzmitry Miranovich (01:03.241)
finance organization, HR organization, recruiting organization, and so forth, but then owns assets which are independent of each other, right? They might be a veterinary business, they might be a HVAC company, they might be a software company. Sometimes Holocaust have very little overhead as well. Sometimes they have a lot of overhead, but that's the model, right? You have businesses that are different in nature from each other.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:17.058)
Mm.


Dzmitry Miranovich (01:31.869)
In roll-ups, the idea is that you buy or partner with handful of businesses in the same industry. And the more similar they are to each other, the better it is. Right. We're talking about GP vet clinics, right. As opposed to, you know, for example, our roll-up, we're doing GP, so general practitioner, veterinary clinics. We do not do urgent care. We do not do emergency. We do not do specialty.


Now some of our clinics might offer occasionally one of the services, whether it's specialty or urgency, urgent care, it gets a little nuanced, but the idea is that you're acquiring businesses that have a very similar model. And, you know, in other industries, you can be doing commercial HVAC, residential HVAC, and those are quite different from each other. So in the roll up idea is that you buy a bunch of businesses that they're similar to each other.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:01.134)
You


Dzmitry Miranovich (02:28.604)
And there is some overarching reason why it makes sense, right? Why one plus one plus one is equal to three or at least three, but ideally more than three, right? Because the important fact to realize is when you put those together, you also have this synergist, right? Like you have corporate overhead, you have corporate cost, you're professionalizing those businesses in many ways, which actually costs money, right? Like running proper.


payroll and accounting accruals, things like that, all of that costs money. And so there is a level of this synergy. And so it's very important to have a thesis whereby, again, one plus one plus one is at least worth three or more. And so there is often some, well, actually, there is rarely a revenue synergy component. It could be some. There might be better ways to run revenue, right? So just grow those faster.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:02.699)
Mm-hmm.


Dzmitry Miranovich (03:26.42)
There is often some sort of cost synergy component, right? And that's, you know, could be margins, could be better ways of running those businesses, better SOPs, better operating procedures, so forth. And then there is also the aspect of diversifying risk or mitigating the risk, right? Like each of those businesses that you partner with or buy are inherently very small businesses that they're, you know, prone to risks. You know, it could be...


loss of a key person, could be geographic risk of being subject to like hurricanes or weather or whatnot, right? So when you put them together, you diversify that away. put them systems in place to mitigate those risks. Like you might have a recruiting organization, right? Like a recruiter and a sourcer at the parent company level, which individual clinics just cannot afford, their individual companies cannot afford.


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:17.218)
Well, I think, I think, I think of holdcos is like an inch deep and a mile wide and roll ups as an inch wide and a mile deep. But there are a lot of people who look at a Warren Buffett. He's got a holdco. I want to be like Warren Buffett. Well, Warren Buffett has multi-billion dollar positions and he's not the one who's actually running these businesses. It's very different when you have a holdco and you are responsible for operational execution. Then when you are someone like Warren Buffett who


Dzmitry Miranovich (04:31.284)
You


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:43.842)
has enough resources to hire out the depth and the bench of the team in order to execute really, really well. What made you decide to go the roll-up route? Because for people who are listening, typically what happens in a roll-up, the idea, the thesis is, look, we can go out and we can identify an industry, and we can raise capital. And with that capital, we are going to go and buy a bunch. We'll have a platform, and then we'll be able to consolidate and centralize either some of these things, the synergies that you were talking about. We'll either centralize some services, or we'll use those synergies to achieve better margins.


But then you grow and at scale, have cost efficiencies that you couldn't otherwise achieve by bootstrapping. However, you have to raise money and you kind of go into other investors and they're putting money into your business. There's some level of, I don't necessarily have full control, even though I am operating as an entrepreneur. For you, like why decide to go the roll up? Why not decide to maybe buy a business first, operate that, grow it and just rinse and repeat.


Dzmitry Miranovich (05:41.97)
Yeah, I think it.


There are several things to it, right? In a whole comodo, you're inherently buying a bunch of different businesses and different industries, right? So I think it's fundamentally difficult, or not necessarily difficult, just takes time to get really smart in an industry, right? To get really good at something, right?


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:55.384)
Mm-hmm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (06:05.619)
totally agree, totally agree.


Dzmitry Miranovich (06:09.38)
And so in my mind, like, so we've been doing this for three to four years. you know, I can tell, like, you know, in my prior job, I worked for large investment firm, you know, I covered several different industries, including veterinary services. And so I knew the industry well, I thought. But then it turns out like sitting in a Manhattan, you know, high rise office building and like, you know, looking at numbers and thinking, I know this industry really well.


Turns out that doesn't really give you the crats to know the industry. When you actually step into the role, you're like, my God, like this is so different. Like the reality is so much more complicated and questions that we used to ask don't really matter. There's those questions that we should have asked and we've never asked because we didn't even think about it.


Nikolas Hulewsky (06:58.37)
What were you doing at Carlyle? So when you say you were sitting and looking at a spreadsheet, what functions were you actually doing?


Dzmitry Miranovich (07:05.256)
Yeah, so I was an investment professional. I worked in the product credit side. So we did everything from junior debt to senior debt, specials is directly ending everything in between. And so we were with the investments in several vet consolidators and also like dental and physical therapy and dermatology and many other industries, right? But to guess to your point, right? Like


Now that I know what I know, I think it would be incredibly difficult to just say, I'm going to buy an HVAC business one year and then next year I'm going to buy.


of that business and actually I'm going to buy a dental business. I think it's perfectly fine, right? If you have a management team to run those businesses, right? And you're partnering with someone who knows those industries really well, which oftentimes is the seller, right? If that's the whole cost set up, I can get behind it. I think it makes sense why people do it, how people do it. And like independent sponsor model in some ways is sort of doing that, right? Except that there's no common ownership.


Nikolas Hulewsky (07:48.654)
Mm-hmm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (08:06.914)
Yeah. I, I, I dabbled in a hold co. mean, we didn't have a ton of companies, but, I realized really quickly that I hated it because there's a lot of context switching and unless you're at scale and have management teams, the execution is on you. And it's really hard to have expertise in five different businesses. It's very difficult.


If you don't have a thesis, I think the hold goes that I've seen be successful is they may not be rolling up a vertical, but they've identified something where they say, we look for, don't know, businesses that are lagging on technological adoption specifically with AI. And then they'll go and they'll kind of apply that broadly. And they have a centralized team that has one specialty. And so that becomes sort of the differentiator. But if you were like me and just a shotgun approach, like, this is a cool tree trimming business.


Dzmitry Miranovich (08:40.691)
Mm-hmm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (09:00.718)
Oh, this is a cool digital agency or this is a cool RV park. That thesis kind of fails because there is no thesis and you really have to understand what you're doing.


Dzmitry Miranovich (09:09.906)
Yeah, unless you have a very strong management team that runs each of those businesses, right? And typically to have that, you need to be buying assets of certain size, right? Those companies have to be big enough to afford the dedicated management team, right? And dedicated management resource. so, yeah, I mean, think Holka Model could totally work. It's just, you know, you have to be mindful of that. Like in my mind, then, like I decided, you know,


Nikolas Hulewsky (09:14.57)
Exactly. Yep, which I didn't.


Nikolas Hulewsky (09:21.837)
Mm-hmm.


Dzmitry Miranovich (09:38.645)
I looked at several industries, I evaluated them based on certain parameters. I'm happy to dive into that and I decided, okay, this is the industry I want to go after, let's dive in. I felt I knew the industry turned out that my knowledge was a lot more like spreadsheet knowledge than actual knowledge. But then I learned and I think...


So if you ask me like, what is the key quality that's in my mind as a predictor of doing this well, and I hope we're doing it well, is just like basically blocking and tackling, right? That's just having, and someone, someone told me that's a serial roll up founder is now like, you know, acquired and sold several, you know, roles in multiple industries. was the same thing he said to me. was like, it's just blocking and tackling. You just got to persevere. You just got to.


dive in, learn, you'll face a lot of new problems, a lot of new things that you've never dealt with before. And maybe that's just with, any business and you just have to tackle them one by one and stay positive and do it.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:50.19)
So let's go high level and then we can go granular on vet clinics. What makes a good industry to do a roll-up in? Or at least, what are the key characteristics that you look for to say, I could do a roll-up in this space?


Dzmitry Miranovich (11:05.64)
Yep. So it has to be fragmented, right? So it has to be, there has to be ideally thousands of individual small businesses operating within DaemonStream. There has to...


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:18.774)
And is there a is there like a concentration percentage that you look for? Because obviously, can be thousands of businesses, but you have one company that has 80 % of the market. That's not fragmented.


Dzmitry Miranovich (11:26.452)
Yeah, exactly that wouldn't work. know, I'd say if industry is over 50 % consolidated, I probably wouldn't go for it. There is very rarely like one company that's, you know,


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:37.004)
Okay. Okay.


Dzmitry Miranovich (11:42.151)
a large percentage of the entire industry, at least in the US, right? In some like Western European markets, it's more common. Like, for example, VetMed in Europe, in the UK, there's one company that's, I won't say 20 to 25 % of all vet clinics in the UK are owned by one company. In the, you know, it's much smaller market, much easier, quicker to consolidate. In the US, know, largest player probably owns like single digit percentage number of all vet clinics across multiple brands.


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:59.15)
Mm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (12:09.582)
Yeah, what I would say like the flip of that would be electronic medical records, for example, like in the hospital systems, epics dominating or like in the skilled nursing space or home health and hospice, like the EHRs, it's probably not a space you're to go do a roll up in just because there is heavy consolidation. But in the clinic space, you mentioned like physical therapy, occupational therapy, home health, hospice, there's a lot of fragmentation in those spaces. There's not a ton of consolidation.


Dzmitry Miranovich (12:17.469)
Yeah.


Dzmitry Miranovich (12:35.378)
Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. So I would say, like vertical therapy software, there's like bazillion of them, right? There is, HVAC, dental, dermatology, physical therapy, mainly like trampoline parks. Like there, there is fitness gyms, right? There is various degrees of consolidation in each of those industries. Right? So


Nikolas Hulewsky (12:44.558)
Mm-hmm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (12:57.812)
that's interesting. So you would even look at that as like, that's an ERP. So actually the ERP market is all of these different EHRs and backend systems that are managing these businesses. Dzmitry Miranovich (13:13.372)
Yeah. And yeah, and people doing that, like, first co-ERPs, like, they would buy ERP for, like, meat processing and the ERP for, a cookie factor and ERP for, I don't even know, like, cogs.


Nikolas Hulewsky (13:20.45)
Mm-hmm.

Well, because you have, yeah, you have ERPs like Monday's not the word. What is it? my gosh, I'm blanking on it. I'm looking at them right now. Anyways, where they're fully integrated and they're managing everything and they can apply to like almost any industry, but they're just overbilled and they're not at work day. That's geez Louise. That freaking took me forever to go. Yeah, like work day applies to almost any industry, but there's not a lot of specificity to your particular business.


Dzmitry Miranovich (13:48.296)
Word they, yeah.

Okay, sorry, I got a soft track. the first one is fragmentation, less than 50 % consolidation.


Dzmitry Miranovich (13:58.677)
Yeah. So fragmented market, let's say, you know, it's arbitrary to be fair. It's arbitrary, right? Less than 50 % consolidated, but it's important that when you look at the overall market, you also need to look at what's your addressable market. Like for example, HVAC, right? There's like a bazillion HVAC companies in the U.S. and most of them or many of them are


Nikolas Hulewsky (14:05.399)
Mm-hmm.


Dzmitry Miranovich (14:27.3)
single technician, a specialist and a truck and that's the entire business. And it still counts as an HVAC business. Now that will never get acquired. I mean, it's very difficult to your head around acquiring something like that because it's too small in terms of revenue. It's concentration risk was one that's called provider specialist, right? So you need to narrow it down from all of the businesses in the specific industry down to which can be


Nikolas Hulewsky (14:30.051)
Mm-hmm.


Dzmitry Miranovich (14:55.856)
actually acquired or partnered with. And then you need to look at the fragmentation of that pie. Because oftentimes you might realize, like, example, dental industry, mean, there's all kinds of stats floating around of consolidation in the dental industry. But if you look at the addressable market, I mean, think it's 60 to 80 % consolidated. And so it's important to look, so fragmented industry, then fragmented addressable part of the industry.


Nikolas Hulewsky (15:16.952)
Mm-hmm.


Dzmitry Miranovich (15:25.17)
So that's number one. And then the extension of that is you want to have a runway for consolidation, right? You want to be able to do this for five, 10, 15, 20 years, because that's what supports your multiple arbitrage. You buy your individual asset for X ebita, you sell it for two X or one and half X, right? And those kinds of ratios differ and...


In the perfect world, your roll up thesis should not depend on multiple arbitrage. Your economics, your operational value creation should drive returns. And that's what we strive for internally. But you know, you want to have this kind of multiple arbitrage as a sort of chair on top. And quite frankly, that chair could be more like a pineapple. So, and that's support and that's supported by runway for consolidation, right? Because the longer the runway, the longer you can make an argument that you can be by.


Nikolas Hulewsky (16:11.832)
What's up?


Dzmitry Miranovich (16:20.658)
bind down the multiple rates.

How do you measure runway for consolidation? Just what percentage of the market is consolidated and then how large the total addressable market is?

Yeah. Yeah. Like in most industries, can find industry publications. Sometimes industry might have like a dedicated or like a blue cheap brokerage firm that operates within that niche, within that industry. They would track those numbers and it's a whole bunch of estimates, of course. Right. But you know, you can get the sense of it, right? There is a, let's say, you know, 10,000 units and 3000 are consolidated.


addressable market. Let's say 10,000 is the addressable market, right? 3,000 are consolidated and 500 are being sold per year, roughly, right? And so you divide that kind of 10 minus three, seven by 500 and you get your runway, right? So that's kind of the, and you'll never achieve like 100 % consolidation, and you'll never achieve like 100 % consolidation, but maybe you sold from like, you know, that this case I'm.

that's really interesting.

talking about like from 30 % to like 60%. So that how long will it take for that 30%, 30 points of consolidation to happen, right? And you can.

Okay, I've never heard of that equation before. Let me like split that back to you. So if there's 10,000 companies in an industry, 3,000 are consolidated. So there's 7,000 free agents. And you go to that blue chip brokerage.

Yep. Yep. And let's say there's 10,000 that are addressable. Those are the companies that can actually be a

Right. And then you go to that blue chip brokerage and you, or you talk to a few of them and you kind of decide, I have this 500 a year that are being sold. If you divide that 7,000 by 500, that's 14. So is that like, it's my runway is 14 years. Is that how you look at it?

Yeah, yeah, exactly.

is there a is there a range like it.

And so in this specific example, maybe it's not 14 years, maybe it's more like 10 years. But yeah, that's the exact math you want to do in your head as you're looking at the industry. Say it again?


Nikolas Hulewsky (18:22.424)
Sure, but it's a proxy.

Okay, you want a decade plus. Dude, that is fascinating. I've never heard that before. Is that unique to you?

Nikolas Hulewsky (19:22.647)
Yeah.

Yeah.

Nikolas Hulewsky (19:51.074)
Yeah.

Okay, so fragmentation, I put total addressable market as a separate category. I know that you kind of put it in with fragmentation, I do think you want to have, there has to be a market of some minimum viable size. then this, I.

No, please.

in an industry is just tiny, right? That's maybe like four or 500 K of revenue. And so it's just difficult to roll those up, right? you know, managing 10 veterinary clinics that generate, you know, one million of revenue is about the same effort as managing 10 that generate two or three million of revenue each. Right. So, and I would target, you know, I mean, you, you want to get to a point where

Hmm.

On personality fit with, you know, doctors who partner with us, who sell to us, who stay on as co-owners, partners, that's, cause that's core to our model. Like we have a co-ownership model. We didn't pay that much attention to size.


Nikolas Hulewsky (23:04.525)
You

Nikolas Hulewsky (23:58.126)
Totally. Well, and like you were saying, it's very different when, excuse my language here, I call it spreadsheet porn. yes, it does. Okay, great. Now I'm going to go get my first acquisition. You're not necessarily at least from what you're saying. Yeah.

not having any track record basically. I sort of disagree with that in a way that like we wanted to make sure that our deals, you we had very strong fit, culturally, partnership wise, like from day one, right? It might not have, you know,

Right, right.

we didn't look at certain parameters like maybe size as much as we're looking at them now. The most important thing for us, day one, was to partner with the right people because if your first or second or third acquisition turns out to be problematic, it just drags down the entire thing.


Nikolas Hulewsky (26:17.422)
Well, yeah, I totally agree. I was talking to somebody last week and they were, they want to do a roll up. And so they were kind of telling me their strategy and they found this. You don't know anything about the space.


Dzmitry Miranovich (26:32.766)
Okay.


Nikolas Hulewsky (26:45.866)
and this owner wants to retire, et cetera, et cetera. But worst of all, when the owner retires, you have to jump in and operate the business and there's no SOPs, there's no processes to get it going. So when you're doing that first acquisition, it's incredibly important to know what you need. Like if you had operated vet clinics before, maybe you get into the business and you don't necessarily need the owner to stay around or a good partner. Okay. But if you've never operated before, like you're saying, no, I need to have a partner. need to have either systems or processes or it needs to be large enough that I can go in and run it.


To your point, that first acquisition is so important, but it's not necessarily one size fits all of how it has to look.
